title: Montague Lush
text:
Sir Charles Montague Lush (7 December 1853 – 22 June 1930) was a British judge.
The son of the judge <a href="Robert%20Lush">Sir Robert Lush</a>, Lush was educated at <a href="Westminster%20School">Westminster School</a> and at <a href="Trinity%20Hall%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity Hall, Cambridge</a>, where he took a <a href="British%20undergraduate%20degree%20classification">First</a> in Classics in 1876. He was <a href="Call%20to%20the%20bar">called to the bar</a> by <a href="Gray%27s%20Inn">Gray's Inn</a> in 1879, and joined the North Eastern Circuit. He <a href="Queen%27s%20Counsel">took silk</a> in 1902.
In 1910, Lush was appointed to the <a href="High%20Court%20of%20Justice">High Court</a> and assigned to the <a href="King%27s%20Bench%20Division">King's Bench Division</a>, receiving the customary <a href="Knight%20Bachelor">knighthood</a> on 13 October 1910. In 1915 he was appointed as President of the <a href="Railway%20and%20Canal%20Commission">Railway and Canal Commission</a>. He retired from the bench in 1925 due to deafness, and was made a Privy Counsellor the same year, although he never sat on the <a href="Judicial%20Committee%20of%20the%20Privy%20Council">Judicial Committee of the Privy Council</a>.
Although highly regarded as a barrister, he was not a successful judge: he was said to be too diffident and sometimes let personal feelings influence his decisions.
